title: "New game" new meta.
body:
Why is the duo lane still bottom? There have been some pretty big changes this pre-season and I am starting to wonder if the old meta still comes out ahead.

Why isn't the duo lane going mid now? The advantages are pretty big. The biggest advantage being that with the duo mid you have easy access to both dragon **AND the new rift Herald**. If your duo has any advantage mid (or if the other team is doing solo mid) you can push out the mid lane and go 3 man Rift Herald easily with jungler (or 4 man with top) before the other team has a chance to respond. Then you use baron empowered minions in the midlane to take the tower, and since the new game is very snowbally you can quickly move your "mid duo" top or bottom to take another tower and win the game. This advantage will be even bigger once the winnions change hits in 5.23

The only disadvantage that I see for doing this is that your "mid-laner" suffers because he is easier to gank bottom and no longer has easy access to blue. But there are a lot of current mid-laners who have safe wave-clear and decent escape, and there is opportunity to "cross-map" now.

Whether or not this strategy actually is better then the current strategy of sending the duo bot it still brings up a big question. What would it take to change 5 years of players running the same meta with small changes to what champions go to which spots? Is there even a set of in-game changes that will alter lane assignments?

>OFFICIALLY get to decide the meta

Sorry but no, that's not what the word "Meta" means.  This:
>Any playstyle that requires actual thought is automatically shunned if it doesn't conform to what League players unquestioningly rely on from ancient League meta history.

Is completely, totally true for the general League playerbase; not saying differently.  And it's a pretty sad reality.  But nobody "officially" decides meta, that's not how the concept works.

Yeah, I know. I honestly should have more respect for the meta, or at least what it GENUINELY refers to. What meta LEGITIMATELY refers to is ALWAYS a preferable strategy. It has inherently positive connotation. It's like the word "good". Saying "I hate the meta" is like saying "I hate good". What do you MEAN you hate good?

But I think we agree that most people are overconfident in what IS meta. And once they can tag something with "meta", they use that tag as the be all and end all justification for unquestioning support of a playstyle. They rely on the "it's good because it's meta" argument, which is like saying "it's meta because it's meta" or "it's good because it's good". That's not an argument at all. There are REASONS why certain strategies are commonly useful (other than "let's do it like they do in the LCS", which is all people think about). If you think about the reasons, you'll realize these strategies aren't the ONLY useful strategies, or the ONLY correct choice in every situation, or somehow inherently effective regardless of player skills, or ALWAYS effective FOREVER in a continuously morphing game, or effective when the reasons for the strategies no longer hold.

A duo sustain/damage botlane is great for early dragon secures, for instance, which is one of many reasons adc and support are preferable there. But who cares if no one is coordinating early dragons? Which happens all the time in random matchmaking. Ultimately, people are more laid back, and heck, maybe not even warding deep river two thirds of the time. And what if the two people you INSIST on going bot, and doing so as support/adc (because "the meta") would roflstomp with their favorite fighter champs against a fairly mid-skill-level enemy botlane? What if those two people suck at support and adc, and would quickly lose as such? Where's your drag control or late game now? What if you're team isn't good at peeling? So much for a late game comp when you're "late game" champ can't do anything, because a) the player's not great at kiting and b) any attempt at dps is immediately met with death.

People can't take a good strategy, strip away every aspect of skill and/or related strategies it's dependent on, and treat it like law anyway. But they do. "I don't care if you suck and lose the game, as happens for precisely 50% of ALL teams, traditional or not, just as long as you don't suck and lose the game as Xin bot, because then I will give you \*\*\*\* to no end for that pick the moment you hit 0/1/assists-what-are-those."

If people would start thinking of meta as an adjective instead of a pronoun, we might make some headway in people actually THINKING about why they're doing what they're doing, why OTHER people are doing what they're doing, and not running the guilt-trip gauntlet the moment someone tries a strategy that isn't "THE" meta. Here's an (unintentionally) long story to make my point:

I won 9 out of 10 duo placements a couple seasons back using double-heal botlane, synergizing old Soraka's e mana-heal with Sona's heal for infinite sustain. It screwed up a lot of traditional botlaners who didn't counter-strategize to quickly burst-kill a couple of squish with poor escape using some ganks. Strategizing? What's that? Instead, the enemies would always run down mana dishing out the usual everyday botlane pokes, which, in this circumstance, were TERRIBLE choices. We obviously recovered from them quickly and indefinitely.

Occasionally, they'd go for the burst kill, but that was without jungle+mid, or maybe with jungle, but without the right burst synergy, and they'd never count the costs of our unusual summoner spell setups (barriers for ignites, heals for when the ignites wore off, no flash, 'cause the bait was real). If they went in, they'd die before we did with that setup. The thought that, without flash, more frequent mid/jungle combo ganks would be freelo just doesn't occur to a team of people randomly matched with each other. Only the thought of "they don't have an adc, so we MUST outtrade" passed their minds, in EVERY GAME. As a result, we roflstomped lane and midgame in every one but two out of those 10 games. And I mean ROFLSTOMPED. No team recovered even slightly in 8 out of those 10 games after we had major kill/objective leads in the lower half of the map. Even if enemy toplaner also roflstomped, we would then, midgame, shut that down too.

What happened in chat in the two games we DIDN'T win GLORIOUSLY from minute 1? Well, one of our allies, Lee Sin punches away at a taric in a mid-siege skirmish while a vayne 3 feet away, not even moving, just free-pokes him to death for about 7 seconds. He wouldn't stop basic attacking taric the whole time, or move back, or turn to vayne after the initial stun. Lee was right in front of our tower. If I didn't know better, I would have assumed that was an intentional feed. All he had to do was back up a little and stop "chasing the singed", so to speak. Once he inevitably died, he said, "YOU SEE THAT VAYNE? SHE IS CARRYING THEIR TEAM" to give us a "lesson" in the meaning of "carry" and why it was clear the lack of a strict "ad carry" bot was the reason ham-spamming taric with a wide-open squish-nuker practically in melee range didn't work out for him (the connections... so strong). The importance of carries would be a nice lesson to consider, if I wasn't busy thinking the honest truth for this particular situation, "no, Lee, YOU'RE carrying their team."

In one of those two postgames, one of our allies goes, "guys, don't ever do that again". Right, sure. If only we went TRADITIONAL carry/support botlane, 'cause then we would have won... like we did every time until my internet crapped out one game. Um, I'm sorry, I thought the point of the "meta" was to win. ISN'T that the point? We won overwhelmingly while carrying over and over again. Wait, no, doesn't matter, gotta ignore that fact. If it's not "THE" meta, then it's bad, BY DEFINITION, and therefore shouldn't be done. 

If ONLY we had chose to do something "good", like, a traditional carry/support botlane that would have lost us 5 out of 10 games, the average, given our skill level. But THAT'S OKAY, because "THE" meta choices are "good" choices and if that causes us to lose 5 times as often, that's irrelevant, because it's "good", and what we successfully did to win is "bad".

Barely anyone on any of the teams we were matched with were exceptional, and WE certainly wouldn't have been with our not-so-leet skills in most traditional rolls. It was a bunch of average players, including us. Case in point: no enemy botlaners could seem to get a freakin' clue what was up when they saw a Sona/Raka no-flash barrier/heal botlane until it was too late. Most of them were too busy thinking "woot, free victory" telling from chat... and, pretty much not thinking otherwise, apparently. If they hadn't been so stuck up about "THE" meta that they understood very little about, except how to pronounce it, they could have easily taught us a lesson in "meta" by effectively countering our strategy with easily coordinated jungle/mid ganks to burst through all of our defenses and punish our lack of mobility. But since most players don't actually KNOW what the meta they hold dear means, it's not surprising those teams failed (miserably) at fighting us in their "freelo" game against "troll" botlaners.

This was a good post.

The only reason mid can do it is either A. they have a dash or speedbust or B. They have heavy CC to prevent the gank or a combination of both. Poke supports will suffer in this scenario(since they will be the most vulnerable to ganks since they posses the less reliable escapes)  and all in supports will also fall off meta since they won't be able to do anything during the laning phase to get ahead and don't become useless. The only supports that would trill would be disengage supports (such as alistar or janna and maybe lulu) and sustain supports ( such as soraka, the only real sustain support,  and maybe nami; although nami is more of a poke support).

Well, they can solo lane in the sense of going against another solo laner, like top.  Or if the enemy laneswaps, they can stay bot solo.  

But if you're an early adopter of the mage+support mid meta, then you're probably sending your marksman into a *1v2* lane.  (It can't become the new meta if it can't beat the old meta when they go head to head.)

So your marksman is probably up against another marksman *and* a Thresh or whatever.  I don't see how they're going to get out of that alive, let alone with decent farm.

Severely depends on the match-ups (plural, mind you!), if you ask me.

Like, sending Kog'Maw against Graves+Thresh is a suicide mission.

I think Caitlyn and Graves could manage it, since Graves gets burstier with level and he can get innately tanky, and Caitlyn's mobility, zoning, and I believe her aa extendors (I really don't know what to call her new mechanics) can handle it.

But, that's only one side of the coin. If I, or whoever else, decided to adopt duo mid, it would require putting the pressure on those neutral objectives and the enemy laning opponent(s). Sure, your bot is now 1v2, but *so is the enemy's midlane.* I mean, if you go duo mid for the sake of duo mid and do nothing with it, you're not accomplishing anything except for that pointless 1v2 bot lane. 

I think it's worth a shot. One way to see if it's starting to work is if the enemy support heads mid or bot and mid lane swap. That's an indicator of pressure. I've seen 1v2 lanes handle just fine, either through double jungling or your standard lane swapping. It's not impossible, but it's probably going to be hard to get people to cooperate at first (and forcing them wouldn't be okay either!).

I think duo mid would be pretty bad. You are putting one of your (theoretically) hardest to gank lanes in the shortest, safest lane on the map. Not to mention, it would be so easy to collapse on a mage type character solo bot.

Usually, player distribution is the most resilient part of the meta. If the lanes are uneven, this is usually really bad. When a team plays a duo top and the supp goes with the bruiser, the adc is left alone bot. In the top lane, the solo top laner will most likely have more aoe, tankiness and cc to defend against the waves pushing on them. On the other hand, the lone adc is gonna be against a good lane pusher and support, while they will probably have subpar or expensive waveclear. Another thing with uneven games is exp difference. The solo laner will be much stronger than the duo, but the adc can't do too much with that size of an advantage yet, but the top laner can probably 2v1. Once there's a 2v1 for a few minutes, you can't change back. That makes everything worse. So games with different lane positions often end horribly so the meta can't change without everyone doing the same line up
